default.prompt: What is the primary architectural difference between 'v-if' and 'v-show'?
options: v-if is for components, v-show is for HTML tags.
v-if conditionally renders/destroys the element in the DOM; v-show only toggles the CSS 'display' property.
v-if is faster for frequent toggling.
v-show is only available in Vue 2.
default.explanation: v-if is 'real' conditional rendering because it ensures that event listeners and child components inside the conditional block are properly destroyed and re-created. v-show is much simplerâ€”the element always remains in the DOM.
default.interviewTip: Use v-if for conditions that rarely change at runtime; use v-show if you need to toggle something very frequently (like a tab or a tooltip).

default.prompt: Why is it strongly recommended to always provide a unique ':key' when using 'v-for'?
options: To tell Vue which CSS styles to apply.
To help Vue's Virtual DOM track which elements have changed, been added, or removed for efficient patching.
To sort the list automatically.
Keys are required by the browser to render lists.
default.explanation: Without keys, Vue uses an algorithm that minimizes element movement and tries to patch/reuse elements in-place. This can lead to bugs with form state or animations.
default.interviewTip: Never use 'index' as a key if the list can be reordered, filtered, or if items can be deleted. Use unique IDs from your data.

v-for

default.explanation: In Vue 3, v-if has a higher priority than v-for. This means the v-if doesn't have access to variables from the v-for scope, and the code above will likely throw an error because 'item' is not defined when v-if runs.
default.interviewTip: In Vue 2, the priority was reversed. Regardless of the version, you should avoid using both on the same element. Wrap the list in a <template v-for> or use a computed property to filter the list beforehand.

default.explanation: The <template> tag acts as an invisible wrapper. It allows you to use directives like v-if or v-for on a group of elements without affecting the final HTML structure.
default.interviewTip: This is perfect for keeping your DOM tree flat and clean.

default.prompt: Which of these are valid ways to iterate using v-for?
options: v-for="n in 10" (Iterating over a range)
v-for="(value, key) in myObject" (Iterating over object properties)
v-for="item in items" (Iterating over an array)
v-for="char in 'Hello'" (Iterating over a string)
default.explanation: Vue is quite flexible. You can iterate over arrays, objects (value, key, index), and even integer ranges (1 to N). String iteration is technically possible but rarely used in practice.
default.interviewTip: When iterating over an object, the order is based on Object.keys() enumeration order, which may vary across browsers.

default.prompt: What happens if two items in a v-for list have the same ':key'?
options: Vue will automatically generate a new key for one of them.
It will cause a runtime warning and likely lead to unpredictable DOM update bugs.
The app will crash immediately.
Only the first item will be rendered.
default.explanation: Duplicate keys confuse the Virtual DOM's reconciliation process. Vue will warn you in the console, and you may see elements 'flickering' or showing the wrong state when the list changes.
default.interviewTip: Always ensure keys are truly unique within the list.

default.prompt: What is the difference between v-if and v-show?
options: v-if removes the element from the DOM; v-show toggles CSS display property.
v-show is faster than v-if.
v-if works only with components.
There is no difference.
default.explanation: v-if has higher toggle cost (destroys/recreates elements), while v-show has higher initial render cost (renders everything but hides with CSS).
default.interviewTip: Use v-if for infrequent toggles, v-show for frequent toggles.

default.prompt: Why should you avoid using v-if and v-for on the same element?
options: It causes a syntax error.

It makes the code harder to read.
Vue automatically optimizes this pattern.
default.explanation: In Vue 3, v-for has higher priority, so v-if will run on each iteration. This is inefficient. Use a computed property or wrap with a template tag instead.
